The year 2022 was marked by a significant number of tornadoes worldwide, resulting in loss of life and property damage. This article provides an overview of the tornadoes that occurred in different regions of the world, including North America, Europe, Asia, and elsewhere.

#North America

North America experienced a high frequency of tornadoes in 2022, with the United States and Canada being the most affected countries.

##Costliest United States tornadoes

According to data from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), the top 5 costliest tornadoes in the United States in 2022 were:

1. A tornado that occurred on March 21 in New Orleans, Louisiana, causing $1.2 billion in damages.
2. A tornado that occurred on April 29 in Kansas, causing $900 million in damages.
3. A tornado that occurred on May 10 in Oklahoma, causing $700 million in damages.
4. A tornado that occurred on June 13 in Illinois, causing $600 million in damages.
5. A tornado that occurred on July 19 in Michigan, causing $500 million in damages.

article:
2022 World Junior Ice Hockey Championships

The 2022 World Junior Ice Hockey Championships was the 46th edition of the IIHF World Junior Championship, an annual international ice hockey tournament organized by the International Ice Hockey Federation (IIHF) for national under-20 ice hockey teams. The tournament took place from December 26, 2021, to January 5, 2022, in Edmonton and Red Deer, Alberta, Canada.

Background
----------

### Preparations

The 2022 World Junior Ice Hockey Championships was originally scheduled to take place in Gothenburg, Sweden. However, due to the COVID-19 pandemic, the IIHF announced on September 17, 2020, that the 2022 tournament would be relocated to Edmonton and Red Deer, Alberta, Canada. The tournament was organized by Hockey Canada, with the support of the National Hockey League (NHL) and the Canadian Hockey League (CHL).

### Cancellation and rescheduling of tournament due to COVID-19

The 2022 World Junior Ice Hockey Championships was initially set to begin on December 26, 2021. However, on December 29, 2021, the IIHF announced that the tournament would be cancelled due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The decision was made after several teams were forced to withdraw from the tournament due to positive COVID-19 tests among their players and staff.

On December 31, 2021, the IIHF announced that the tournament would be rescheduled to take place from August 9 to 20, 2022. However, on January 3, 2022, the IIHF announced that the tournament would be rescheduled again, this time to take place from August 8 to 19, 2022.

### Sponsorship withdrawals and low attendance

The 2022 World Junior Ice Hockey Championships was affected by several sponsorship withdrawals and low attendance. Several major sponsors, including the NHL and the CHL, withdrew their support for the tournament due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Additionally, attendance at the tournament was significantly lower than expected, with many fans opting not to attend due to concerns about the pandemic.

### Group A (December 2021)

The Group A preliminary round took place from December 26 to 31, 2021, at the Rogers Place in Edmonton, Alberta. The group consisted of Canada, Czech Republic, Finland, and Germany.

### Group B (December 2021)

The Group B preliminary round took place from December 26 to 31, 2021, at the Peavey Mart Centrium in Red Deer, Alberta. The group consisted of Austria, Russia, Sweden, and Switzerland.

Top Division
------------

### Venue

The 2022 World Junior Ice Hockey Championships was held at two venues: the Rogers Place in Edmonton, Alberta, and the Peavey Mart Centrium in Red Deer, Alberta. The Rogers Place has a seating capacity of 18,347, while the Peavey Mart Centrium has a seating capacity of 7,111.

### Match officials

The IIHF selected 12 referees and 12 linesmen to officiate the 2022 World Junior Ice Hockey Championships.

### Rosters

Each team was allowed to have a maximum of 25 players on their roster.

### Teams

Ten teams participated in the 2022 World Junior Ice Hockey Championships:

*  Austria
*  Canada
*  Czech Republic
*  Finland
*  Germany
*  Russia
*  Sweden
*  Switzerland
*  United States

article:
**New England Patriots**

The New England Patriots are a professional American football team based in the Greater Boston region. They are a member of the East division of the American Football Conference (AFC) in the National Football League (NFL). The women's ice hockey tournament at the 2022 Winter Olympics was held from 3 to 17 February 2022 at the Wukesong Arena and the National Indoor Stadium in Beijing, China. Ten teams competed in the tournament, which was the sixth time women's ice hockey had been included in the Winter Olympics.

The top three teams from each group advanced to the playoff round, along with the winner of a qualification playoff between the fourth-place teams from each group.

article:
Scream VI

Scream VI is a 2023 American slasher film directed by Matt Bettinelli-Olpin and Tyler Gillett, and written by James Vanderbilt and Guy Busick. It is the sixth installment in the Scream franchise and a direct sequel to Scream (2022). The film takes place in New York City and follows a new Ghostface killer who begins targeting a group of young people with connections to the original Woodsboro murders.

# Plot

The film opens with a prologue that pays homage to the original Scream, in which a young woman named Laura Crane (Samara Weaving) is attacked and killed by a Ghostface killer in a New York City apartment. The story then shifts to a group of college students, including Mindy Meeks-Martin (Jasmin Savoy Brown), Chad Meeks-Martin (Mason Gooding), and Ethan Landry (Jack Champion), who are all connected to the original Woodsboro murders. As a new Ghostface killer begins to target them, they team up with Gale Weathers (Courteney Cox) and a new character, Detective Bailey (Dermot Mulroney), to uncover the killer's identity and stop the murders.

As the story unfolds, the group discovers that the new Ghostface killer is targeting people who are connected to the original Woodsboro murders, including family members and friends of the original victims. The group also uncovers a dark secret about the original murders and the true identity of the first Ghostface killer. Along the way, the group faces numerous challenges and obstacles, including the return of old characters and the introduction of new ones.

# Cast

* Melissa Barrera as Sam Carpenter
* Jasmin Savoy Brown as Mindy Meeks-Martin
* Mason Gooding as Chad Meeks-Martin
* Jack Champion as Ethan Landry
* Henry Czerny as Dr. Christopher Stone
* Liana Liberato as Quinn Bailey
* Dermot Mulroney as Detective Bailey
* Hayden Panettiere as Kirby Reed
* Courteney Cox as Gale Weathers
* Roger L. Jackson as the voice of Ghostface

# Production

## Development

Scream VI was announced in March 2022, just a few weeks after the release of Scream (2022). The film was developed by Matt Bettinelli-Olpin and Tyler Gillett, who directed the previous film, and James Vanderbilt and Guy Busick, who wrote the screenplay. The film's story was developed in collaboration with Kevin Williamson, who created the original Scream franchise.

## Casting

The film's cast was announced in May 2022, with Melissa Barrera, Jasmin Savoy Brown, Mason Gooding, and Jack Champion reprising their roles from the previous film. Hayden Panettiere, who played Kirby Reed in Scream 4, was also announced as returning to the franchise. Courteney Cox, who played Gale Weathers in the previous films, was also confirmed to return.

### Neve Campbell's involvement

Neve Campbell, who played Sidney Prescott in the previous Scream films, was not involved in Scream VI. Campbell had previously stated that she would not return to the franchise unless the script was "really good". In an interview, Campbell explained that she had decided not to return to the franchise due to a disagreement over her salary.

## Filming

Principal photography for Scream VI began in June 2022 and wrapped in September 2022. The film was shot on location in New York City and Montreal, Quebec, Canada. The film's budget was estimated to be around $35 million.

# Music

The film's score was composed by Marco Beltrami, who previously composed the scores for the Scream franchise. The film's soundtrack features a mix of original songs and classic rock tracks.

# Release

## Marketing

The film's marketing campaign was launched in December 2022, with the release of the first trailer. The trailer featured a mix of action, suspense, and horror elements, and introduced the new Ghostface killer. The film's poster was also released, featuring the tagline "The City Never Sleeps".

## Home media

Scream VI was released on digital platforms on April 25, 2023, and on Blu-ray and DVD on May 16, 2023. The film's home media release includes a number of bonus features, including deleted scenes, behind-the-scenes footage, and a commentary track with the directors.

# Reception

## Box office

Scream VI was a commercial success, grossing over $150 million worldwide on a budget of $35 million. The film opened at number one at the US box office, grossing $19.3 million in its opening weekend.

## Critical response

Scream VI received generally positive reviews from critics, with many praising the film's suspenseful and entertaining storyline. The film holds a 72% approval rating on Rotten Tomatoes, based on 222 reviews, with an average rating of 6.2/10.

## Accolades

Scream VI was nominated for several awards, including the Saturn Award for Best Horror Film and the Teen Choice Award for Choice Movie: Horror.

# Sequel

A seventh installment in the Scream franchise was announced in May 2023, with Matt Bettinelli-Olpin and Tyler Gillett set to return as directors. The film's script is being written by James Vanderbilt and Guy Busick.

# Notes

Scream VI is the first film in the Scream franchise to be set outside of Woodsboro, California. The film's New York City setting was chosen to give the franchise a fresh start and to explore new themes and ideas.

article:
Gogu Rădulescu

Gogu Rădulescu was a Romanian politician and member of the Romanian Communist Party (PCR) who played a significant role in the country's politics from the late 1940s until his downfall in the 1980s. As a prominent figure in the PCR, Rădulescu held various high-ranking positions, including that of Minister of Culture and Minister of Education. He was known for his patronage of the arts and his efforts to promote Romanian culture, but also for his involvement in the country's authoritarian regime and his close relationship with Nicolae Ceaușescu, the country's dictator.

# Biography

## Early life and FSD

Gogu Rădulescu was born on May 20, 1917, in Bucharest, Romania. His early life and education are not well-documented, but it is known that he studied law at the University of Bucharest. Rădulescu became involved in politics at a young age, joining the Union of Communist Youth (UTC) in the mid-1930s. He quickly rose through the ranks of the organization, becoming a key figure in the UTC's leadership. In 1945, Rădulescu became a member of the Romanian Communist Party's (PCR) Central Committee, a position he held until his death.

## Wartime desertion and return

In 1943, Rădulescu was drafted into the Romanian Army, which was fighting on the side of the Axis powers. However, he soon became disillusioned with the war effort and deserted, fleeing to the Soviet Union. There, he joined the Tudor Vladimirescu Division, a unit of Romanian communists who were fighting alongside the Soviets against the Axis powers. Rădulescu returned to Romania in 1945, where he was welcomed back by the PCR and quickly became a key figure in the party's leadership.

## 1952 fall and 1956 recovery

In 1952, Rădulescu fell out of favor with the PCR's leadership, led by Gheorghe Gheorghiu-Dej. He was accused of being a "right-wing deviationist" and was removed from his position on the Central Committee. Rădulescu was also forced to undergo a period of "re-education" in the Soviet Union, where he was subjected to intense ideological indoctrination. However, he recovered his position in 1956, following the death of Gheorghiu-Dej. Rădulescu became a key ally of Nicolae Ceaușescu, who was then rising through the ranks of the PCR.

## With Ceaușescu

Rădulescu's relationship with Ceaușescu was instrumental in his rise to prominence within the PCR. He became one of Ceaușescu's closest advisors, and played a key role in the latter's campaign to become General Secretary of the PCR. When Ceaușescu finally achieved this goal in 1965, Rădulescu was rewarded with a number of high-ranking positions, including that of Minister of Culture. Rădulescu's tenure as Minister of Culture was marked by a period of relative liberalism in Romanian cultural policy. He encouraged the development of a number of artistic and literary movements, and promoted the work of a number of prominent Romanian artists and writers. Rădulescu also became known for his patronage of the Romanian film industry, and played a key role in the development of a number of successful Romanian films. ## Downfall, prosecution, and death

Rădulescu's downfall came in 1984, when he was accused of corruption and removed from his position as Minister of Culture. He was subsequently prosecuted and sentenced to prison, where he died in 1991. Rădulescu's death marked the end of an era in Romanian politics, and he was remembered by many as a symbol of the country's authoritarian regime.

Chronology of the Later Crusades through 1400

The Later Crusades, which took place from the 13th to the 15th century, were a series of military campaigns launched by Christian Europe against the Muslim world, particularly the Ayyubid and Mamluk dynasties in Egypt and the Levant. This article provides a chronology of the key events of the Later Crusades up to 1400, highlighting the major battles, sieges, and diplomatic maneuvers that shaped the course of these conflicts.

# Chronologies of the Crusades in print

There are several chronologies of the Crusades that have been published over the years, each with its own strengths and weaknesses. Some of the most notable include the works of historians such as Riley-Smith, Tyerman, and Asbridge, who have provided detailed and comprehensive accounts of the Crusades. However, it is worth noting that the chronology of the Later Crusades is not always straightforward, and different historians may have varying interpretations of the same events.

# 13th century

## Prior events

The 13th century saw the rise of the Ayyubid dynasty in Egypt and the Levant, which had a profound impact on the course of the Crusades. The Ayyubids were a powerful and well-organized Muslim state that was able to challenge the Crusader kingdoms in the region. In 1187, the Ayyubid leader Saladin conquered Jerusalem, which had been in Crusader hands since 1099. This event marked a significant turning point in the history of the Crusades, as it led to a renewed focus on the recapture of Jerusalem.

## 1270

In 1270, the Eighth Crusade was launched by King Louis IX of France, who sailed to Tunis with a large army. The crusade was a disaster, as Louis died of disease shortly after arriving in Tunis, and the remainder of the army was forced to retreat.

## 1280

In 1280, the Mamluk dynasty came to power in Egypt, marking the beginning of a new era in the history of the Crusades. The Mamluks were a powerful and well-organized Muslim state that would go on to play a major role in the conflicts of the 14th century.

## 1290

In 1290, the Crusader kingdom of Acre was conquered by the Mamluks, marking the end of the Crusader presence in the Holy Land. This event had a profound impact on the course of the Crusades, as it led to a renewed focus on the recapture of the Holy Land.

# 14th century

## 1300

In 1300, the Ninth Crusade was launched by King Philip IV of France, who sailed to the Holy Land with a large army. The crusade was a failure, as Philip was forced to retreat due to a lack of support from the local Christian lords.

## 1310

## 1320

In 1320, the Mamluks launched a successful campaign against the Crusader kingdom of Cyprus, conquering the island and incorporating it into their empire.

## 1330

In 1330, the Crusader kingdom of Armenia was conquered by the Mamluks, marking the end of the Crusader presence in the region.

## 1340

In 1340, the Crusader kingdom of Antioch was conquered by the Mamluks, marking the end of the Crusader presence in the region.

## 1350

In 1350, the Black Death, a pandemic that had begun in Europe, spread to the Middle East, causing widespread death and destruction.

## 1360

In 1360, the Mamluks launched a successful campaign against the Crusader kingdom of Cilicia, conquering the region and incorporating it into their empire.

## 1370

In 1370, the Crusader kingdom of Tripoli was conquered by the Mamluks, marking the end of the Crusader presence in the region.

## 1380

In 1380, the Mamluks launched a successful campaign against the Crusader kingdom of Tyre, conquering the city and incorporating it into their empire.

## 1390

In 1390, the Mamluks launched a successful campaign against the Crusader kingdom of Beirut, conquering the city and incorporating it into their empire.

# 15th century

## 1400

In 1400, the Mamluks launched a successful campaign against the Crusader kingdom of Sidon, conquering the city and incorporating it into their empire. This event marked the end of the Crusader presence in the Holy Land, and the beginning of a new era in the history of the region.

Queue for the lying-in-state of Elizabeth II

The queue for the lying-in-state of Elizabeth II was a large gathering of mourners who waited in line to pay their respects to the late monarch, who died on September 8, 2022. The lying-in-state took place at Westminster Hall in London, England, from September 14 to September 19, 2022. The queue, which became a major event in itself, was a testament to the widespread outpouring of grief and respect for the Queen.

#Precedents

The queue for the lying-in-state of Elizabeth II was not the first of its kind. When Queen Victoria died in 1901, thousands of people lined up to pay their respects to her body lying in state at Westminster Hall. Similarly, when King George VI died in 1952, a large crowd gathered to pay their respects to his body lying in state at Westminster Hall. However, the queue for Queen Elizabeth II's lying-in-state was significantly larger and more extensive than any previous ones.

#Routes

The queue for the lying-in-state of Elizabeth II followed a designated route through central London. The route was carefully planned and managed by the authorities to ensure the safe and orderly movement of the large crowd.

##Main queue

The main queue started at Albert Embankment on the south bank of the River Thames and wound its way along the river to Westminster Bridge. From there, it continued along Whitehall and into Parliament Square, before turning into Westminster Hall. The queue was approximately 5 miles (8 kilometers) long and took several hours to complete.

##Accessible queue

To accommodate people with disabilities and mobility issues, an accessible queue was set up. This queue started at a designated accessible entry point near Westminster Bridge and joined the main queue at a designated point near Parliament Square. The accessible queue was shorter and more manageable, with seating and refreshments provided along the way.

#Length

The queue for the lying-in-state of Elizabeth II was incredibly long, with estimates suggesting that it stretched for over 5 miles (8 kilometers) at its peak. The queue was so long that it took many hours to complete, with some people waiting for over 24 hours to pay their respects to the Queen.

#Organisation

The queue was carefully managed and organized by the authorities, with a large team of staff and volunteers on hand to ensure the safe and orderly movement of the crowd. The queue was divided into sections, with each section being managed by a team of staff and volunteers. The queue was also equipped with amenities such as toilets, refreshments, and seating areas.

##Exemptions from queuing

Some people were exempt from queuing, including those with disabilities and mobility issues, who were able to use the accessible queue. Others, such as members of the armed forces and emergency services, were also exempt from queuing. Additionally, some people were able to avoid queuing by attending special viewing sessions, which were held at designated times for specific groups, such as schoolchildren and community groups.

#Participation and incidents

The queue for the lying-in-state of Elizabeth II was a major event, with thousands of people participating. Despite the large crowd, the queue was generally well-behaved and orderly, with few incidents reported. However, there were some reports of people pushing in and trying to jump the queue, which were quickly dealt with by the authorities. There were also some reports of people becoming unwell due to the long wait and the hot weather, but these were quickly treated by medical staff on hand.

#Responses and media coverage

The queue for the lying-in-state of Elizabeth II received widespread media coverage, with many news outlets reporting on the large crowd and the long wait. The queue was also the subject of much social media commentary, with many people sharing their experiences and photos of the queue on Twitter and other platforms. The queue was widely praised as a testament to the widespread outpouring of grief and respect for the Queen, with many people commenting on the sense of community and camaraderie among those waiting in line.

article:
Gulf and Western Industries
==========================

Gulf and Western Industries was an American conglomerate that dominated the global economy during the mid-20th century. With a diverse portfolio of companies across various industries, Gulf and Western played a significant role in shaping the business landscape of the United States. This article provides an overview of the company's history, highlighting key events, mergers, and leadership that contributed to its growth and eventual restructuring.

History
-------

### Bluhdorn period

Gulf and Western Industries was founded in 1934 as a small holding company by Charles Bluhdorn, a Czech-born entrepreneur. Initially, the company focused on acquiring and managing struggling businesses, leveraging Bluhdorn's expertise in finance and operations. During the 1950s and 1960s, Gulf and Western expanded its portfolio through strategic acquisitions, including the purchase of the Studebaker-Packard Corporation in 1958. This move marked a significant milestone in the company's history, as it gained control of the Studebaker automobile brand and a substantial stake in the automotive industry.

Throughout the 1960s, Gulf and Western continued to grow through a series of acquisitions, including the purchase of the Kayser-Roth apparel company, the Simmons mattress company, and the Paramount Pictures film studio. Under Bluhdorn's leadership, the company's revenue and market value increased significantly, earning him a reputation as a shrewd businessman and deal-maker.

### Early 1980s

The early 1980s marked a period of significant change for Gulf and Western. In 1980, the company divested its stake in the Studebaker automobile brand, selling it to the Volkswagen Group. This move marked a strategic shift away from the automotive industry and towards more profitable ventures. During this period, Gulf and Western also began to focus on its core businesses, including Paramount Pictures, which had become a major contributor to the company's revenue.

In 1983, Gulf and Western acquired the Madison Square Garden Corporation, adding the iconic New York City landmark to its portfolio. This move marked a significant expansion into the sports and entertainment industry, positioning the company for future growth.

### Martin S. Davis restructuring

In 1983, Martin S. Davis, a veteran executive, succeeded Charles Bluhdorn as CEO of Gulf and Western. Under Davis's leadership, the company underwent a significant restructuring, aimed at streamlining operations and improving profitability. During this period, Gulf and Western divested several underperforming businesses, including the Kayser-Roth apparel company and the Simmons mattress company.

In 1989, Davis led the company's acquisition of the Viacom television network, a move that marked a significant expansion into the media industry. This acquisition positioned Gulf and Western as a major player in the global media landscape, with a portfolio of television networks, film studios, and publishing companies.

### Headquarters

Gulf and Western's headquarters were located in New York City, where the company maintained a significant presence throughout its history. The company's executive offices were located in the Paramount Communications Building, a iconic skyscraper in Midtown Manhattan. The building served as a symbol of the company's power and influence, and was often referred to as the "Gulf and Western Building."

Music of the Spheres World Tour

The Music of the Spheres World Tour is a concert tour by British rock band Coldplay, launched in support of their eighth studio album, Music of the Spheres (2021). The tour marks the band's return to live performances after a four-year hiatus and features a unique blend of music, visuals, and sustainability efforts.

# Development

## Background

The Music of the Spheres World Tour was announced on October 14, 2021, with an initial 29-date schedule spanning across North America, Europe, and Latin America. The tour is produced by Live Nation and features a custom-designed stage and production setup. The band worked closely with production designer Misty Buckley to create an immersive experience that incorporates cutting-edge technology and visual effects.

## Ecological plan

As part of their commitment to reducing their carbon footprint, Coldplay has implemented an ecological plan for the tour. The plan includes measures such as using 100% renewable energy, reducing water consumption, and minimizing waste. The band has also partnered with the environmental organization, One Tree Planted, to plant a tree for every ticket sold.

## Fan accessibility

Coldplay has made efforts to ensure that the tour is accessible to fans of all ages and abilities. The band has partnered with the organization, Music Without Barriers, to provide accessible seating and accommodations for fans with disabilities.

## Partnerships

The Music of the Spheres World Tour features partnerships with several brands and organizations, including American Express, SAP, and Earthshot Prize. The partnerships aim to promote sustainability, innovation, and social responsibility.

# Opening acts

The tour features a rotating lineup of opening acts, including Alina Baraz, Izzy Bizu, and Los Unidades.

# Concert synopsis

## Main structure

The concert features a main setlist of approximately 24 songs, including hits from Coldplay's entire discography, as well as new material from Music of the Spheres. The show is divided into four acts, each with its own unique theme and visual aesthetic.

## Changes

Throughout the tour, the band has made changes to the setlist and stage setup. In some shows, the band has performed acoustic versions of songs, while in others, they have incorporated local musicians and instruments.

# Commercial performance

The Music of the Spheres World Tour has been a commercial success, with sold-out shows in many cities. According to Pollstar, the tour has grossed over $100 million in ticket sales.

The tour received positive reviews from critics in North America, with many praising the band's energy and stage presence. Rolling Stone called the show "a visually stunning and aurally thrilling experience."

## Europe

European critics also praised the tour, with The Guardian calling it "a spectacular and emotional ride."

## South America

The tour was well-received in South America, with critics praising the band's ability to connect with local audiences.

## Asia–Pacific

The tour received positive reviews in the Asia-Pacific region, with critics praising the band's energy and stage presence.

# Accolades

The Music of the Spheres World Tour has received several accolades, including a Pollstar Award for Best Tour and a MTV Video Music Award for Best Live Performance.

# Releases

The tour has been documented through several releases, including a live album and a concert film.

# Legacy

The Music of the Spheres World Tour will be remembered as one of the most innovative and sustainable tours of the 2020s. The tour's commitment to reducing its carbon footprint and promoting social responsibility has set a new standard for the music industry.

# Set list

## Details

The setlist for the Music of the Spheres World Tour features a mix of old and new material, including hits like "Viva La Vida," "Paradise," and "A Sky Full of Stars." The setlist also includes songs from the band's latest album, Music of the Spheres.

## Highlights

article:
History of Taiwan

Taiwan, officially known as the Republic of China (ROC), has a rich and diverse history that spans thousands of years. From the earliest indigenous tribes to the present day, Taiwan has been influenced by various cultures, including Chinese, Dutch, Spanish, Japanese, and American. This article provides an overview of the major events and periods in Taiwan's history.

# Prehistory

The earliest human habitation in Taiwan dates back to around 20,000 to 30,000 years ago, during the Paleolithic era. Archaeological evidence suggests that the island was inhabited by various indigenous tribes, including the Amis, Atayal, Bunun, and Paiwan. These tribes developed complex societies, with their own languages, cultures, and traditions. They lived by hunting, gathering, and farming, and were skilled craftsmen, making tools and textiles.

# Chinese contact and settlement

The first recorded Chinese contact with Taiwan was in 239 AD, during the Three Kingdoms period. Chinese fishermen and traders visited the island, and some settled there. However, it was not until the 17th century that large-scale Chinese settlement began. The Chinese brought with them new technologies, such as iron tools and firearms, which had a significant impact on the indigenous population.

## Contact and establishment

In the early 17th century, Chinese pirates and traders began to establish settlements on the island. The most notable of these was Zheng Zhilong, a pirate-turned-privateer who established a base on Taiwan in 1625. Zheng's son, Zheng Chenggong (also known as Koxinga), would later play a significant role in Taiwanese history.

## Piracy

Piracy was a major problem in the waters around Taiwan during the 17th century. Chinese pirates, as well as Japanese and European pirates, preyed on ships passing through the Taiwan Strait. The Dutch and Spanish, who established colonies on the island, also engaged in piracy.

## Japanese trade

During the 17th century, Japan and Taiwan had significant trade relations. Japanese merchants traded with the indigenous population and the Chinese settlers, exchanging goods such as silk, porcelain, and silver.

## Spanish Formosa

In 1626, the Spanish established a colony on Taiwan, which they called Formosa. The Spanish built forts and churches, and introduced Christianity to the island. However, their rule was short-lived, and they were expelled by the Dutch in 1642.

## Dutch colonization

In 1624, the Dutch East India Company established a colony on Taiwan, which they called Fort Zeelandia. The Dutch built forts, churches, and schools, and introduced Western education and culture to the island. They also established trade relations with China and Japan.

## Chinese settlers

During the Dutch period, large numbers of Chinese settlers arrived on the island. They established their own communities, and developed a distinct Taiwanese identity.

## End of Dutch rule

In 1662, the Dutch were expelled from Taiwan by Zheng Chenggong, who established the Kingdom of Tungning.

# Kingdom of Tungning (1661–1683)

## Conquest

Zheng Chenggong, who had been driven out of China by the Qing dynasty, conquered Taiwan in 1662. He established the Kingdom of Tungning, with its capital at Fort Zeelandia.

## Retreat to Taiwan

Zheng Chenggong had been a Ming loyalist, and had fought against the Qing dynasty. However, after his defeat, he retreated to Taiwan, where he established a Ming-style government.

## Sinicization

During the Kingdom of Tungning period, Taiwan underwent significant sinicization. Chinese culture, language, and customs were introduced, and the indigenous population was assimilated into Chinese society.

## Shi Lang

In 1681, the Qing dynasty sent a naval expedition to Taiwan, led by Admiral Shi Lang. Shi Lang defeated the Kingdom of Tungning forces, and the kingdom was annexed by the Qing dynasty.

## End of Zheng rule

The Kingdom of Tungning came to an end in 1683, when it was annexed by the Qing dynasty. Zheng Chenggong's descendants continued to play a significant role in Taiwanese politics, but the kingdom was eventually absorbed into the Qing empire.

# Qing dynasty (1683–1895)

## Annexation

In 1683, the Qing dynasty annexed Taiwan, and it became a province of the empire. The Qing government established a provincial administration, and introduced Chinese law and institutions.

## Taiwan administration

The Qing government established a provincial administration in Taiwan, with its capital at Taipei. The administration was responsible for collecting taxes, maintaining law and order, and promoting economic development.

## Settler expansion (1684–1795)

During the 18th century, large numbers of Chinese settlers arrived on the island. They established their own communities, and developed a distinct Taiwanese identity.

## Administrative expansion (1796–1874)

During the 19th century, the Qing government expanded its administrative control over Taiwan. New prefectures and counties were established, and the island was divided into smaller administrative units.

## Expansion in reaction to crises (1875–1895)

During the late 19th century, Taiwan faced several crises, including the Opium Wars and the First Sino-Japanese War. In response, the Qing government expanded its administrative control over the island, and introduced new policies to promote economic development.

## Rebellions

During the Qing period, there were several rebellions on the island, including the Taiping Rebellion and the Taiwan Rebellion.

## Invasions

Taiwan was also invaded by foreign powers, including the French and the Japanese.

## End of Qing rule

In 1895, Taiwan was ceded to Japan, and the Qing dynasty's rule came to an end.

# Japanese Empire (1895–1945)

## Armed resistance

After the Japanese took control of Taiwan, there was armed resistance from the Taiwanese people. The resistance was led by the Taiwanese militia, which fought against the Japanese occupation.

## Non-violent resistance

There was also non-violent resistance, led by Taiwanese intellectuals and activists. They advocated for Taiwanese rights and autonomy, and opposed Japanese rule.

## Assimilation movement

During the Japanese period, there was an assimilation movement, which aimed to assimilate the Taiwanese people into Japanese culture. The movement promoted Japanese language and culture, and encouraged Taiwanese people to adopt Japanese customs and practices.

## Education

The Japanese government introduced a new education system, which promoted Japanese language and culture. Taiwanese children were required to attend Japanese-language schools, and were encouraged to adopt Japanese customs and practices.

## Japanization

The Japanese government promoted Japanization, which aimed to assimilate the Taiwanese people into Japanese culture. Taiwanese people were encouraged to adopt Japanese customs and practices, and were required to speak Japanese.

## Aboriginal policies

The Japanese government introduced policies to assimilate the indigenous population into Japanese culture. The policies aimed to promote Japanese language and culture, and to encourage the indigenous population to adopt Japanese customs and practices.

## Japanese colonists

During the Japanese period, large numbers of Japanese colonists arrived on the island. They established their own communities, and developed a distinct Japanese identity.

## Industrialization

The Japanese government promoted industrialization, and introduced new technologies and industries to the island. Taiwan became an important industrial center, and its economy grew rapidly.

## World War II

During World War II, Taiwan played an important role in the Japanese war effort. The island was used as a base for Japanese military operations, and Taiwanese soldiers fought on behalf of the Japanese.

## End of Japanese rule

In 1945, Japan was defeated in World War II, and Taiwan was returned to China. The Japanese period came to an end, and Taiwan began a new era of development.

# Republic of China (1945–present)

## Taiwan under martial law

After the Japanese period, Taiwan was placed under martial law by the Nationalist government. The government introduced strict controls, and suppressed opposition and dissent.

## Economic development

During the 1950s and 1960s, Taiwan experienced rapid economic development. The government introduced new industries and technologies, and the economy grew rapidly.

## Democratic reforms

In the 1980s, Taiwan began to introduce democratic reforms. The government introduced new laws and institutions, and opposition parties were allowed to participate in politics.

## Democratic period

In 1996, Taiwan held its first direct presidential election, and the democratic period began. The government introduced new laws and institutions, and opposition parties were allowed to participate in politics.

# See also

* History of China
* History of Japan
* Taiwanese independence movement
* Taiwan Strait

# Notes

* This article is a general overview of the history of Taiwan. For more detailed information, please see the specific articles on each period.
* The history of Taiwan is complex and multifaceted, and this article cannot cover all aspects of the subject.

# References

* Cited sources:
	+ Andrade, Tonio. "The Island of Formosa Past and Present". 2015.
	+ Chang, Pin-tsun. "The Romantic Sojourner: Shen Fu's Notes from a Floating City". 2009.
* General references:

	+ Gordon, Leonard H. D. "The Taiwan Story". 2013.
	+ Kerr, George H. "Formosa Betrayed". 1965.

article:
Big Brother 25 (American season)

Big Brother 25 is the twenty-fifth season of the American reality television series Big Brother. The season premiered on July 6, 2023, and concluded on September 25, 2023.

# Format

The format of Big Brother 25 saw several changes and additions compared to previous seasons.

## Format changes and additions

### BB Break-in and BB Multiverse

The season introduced a new twist called "BB Break-in" and "BB Multiverse". The BB Break-in twist allowed fans to break into the Big Brother house and steal prizes, including the power of veto. The BB Multiverse twist involved a series of alternate realities, each with its own set of challenges and rewards.

### BB Multiverse

The BB Multiverse twist was a key part of the season's format. The twist involved four different universes, each with its own unique theme and challenges.

#### Comic-verse

The Comic-verse universe was a humorous take on the Big Brother experience. Houseguests in this universe competed in comedic challenges and were rewarded with funny prizes.

#### Humili-verse

The Humili-verse universe was a more serious take on the Big Brother experience. Houseguests in this universe competed in challenges that pushed them to their limits and were rewarded with prizes that were designed to humiliate them.

#### Scary-verse

The Scary-verse universe was a horror-themed take on the Big Brother experience. Houseguests in this universe competed in challenges that were designed to scare them and were rewarded with prizes that were creepy and unsettling.

#### Scramble-verse

The Scramble-verse universe was a fast-paced take on the Big Brother experience. Houseguests in this universe competed in challenges that required them to think quickly and make fast decisions.

### Smaller jury

The season also saw a smaller jury compared to previous seasons. The jury consisted of nine members, rather than the usual 12 or 13.

# Houseguests

The season saw 16 new houseguests enter the Big Brother house.

## Future appearances

Several houseguests from Big Brother 25 have gone on to appear in other reality TV shows and competitions.

# Episodes

The season consisted of 36 episodes, which aired over the course of three months.

# Voting history

The voting history of the season saw several twists and turns, with multiple houseguests being evicted and new alliances forming.

# Production

The production of Big Brother 25 was overseen by Allison Grodner and Rich Meehan.

## Development

The development of the season began several months before the premiere, with casting calls and auditions taking place across the country.

## Casting

The casting process for the season was overseen by Robyn Kass, who has been the casting director for Big Brother since its inception.

## Production design

The production design of the season was overseen by Scott Storey, who has been the production designer for Big Brother since season 15.

# Release

The season premiered on July 6, 2023, and concluded on September 25, 2023.

## Broadcast

The season was broadcast on CBS, with episodes airing three times a week.

## Streaming

The season was also available to stream on the CBS All Access platform, which allowed fans to watch episodes online and on-demand.

# Reception

The season received mixed reviews from critics and fans.

## Critical responses

The season was criticized for several reasons, including the use of ethnic slurs by one houseguest and the lack of accessibility for another houseguest.

### Luke Valentine's usage of an ethnic slur

Houseguest Luke Valentine was criticized for using an ethnic slur during a conversation with another houseguest. The incident sparked outrage among fans and critics, with many calling for Valentine's removal from the show.

### Accessibility issues for Matt Klotz

Houseguest Matt Klotz, who is deaf, was criticized for the lack of accessibility on the show. Fans and critics pointed out that the show did not provide adequate accommodations for Klotz, including a lack of interpreters and closed captions.

### Jared Fields's usage of an ableist slur

Houseguest Jared Fields was criticized for using an ableist slur during a conversation with another houseguest. The incident sparked outrage among fans and critics, with many calling for Fields's removal from the show.

### Allegations of bias and inequity

The season was also criticized for allegations of bias and inequity, with several houseguests accusing the show of favoring certain contestants over others. Fans and critics pointed out that the show's twists and challenges seemed to benefit certain houseguests more than others, leading to accusations of bias and favoritism.

Bigg Boss (Hindi TV series) season 16 is the sixteenth season of the Indian reality TV series Bigg Boss, which premiered on Colors TV on 1 October 2022. The show is hosted by Salman Khan and produced by Endemol Shine India.

# Production

## Broadcast
The season premiered on 1 October 2022 on Colors TV and streamed on JioCinema. The show is broadcast from Monday to Friday at 10:00 pm IST and on Saturday and Sunday at 9:30 pm IST.

## Casting
The casting for the season began in June 2022, and the contestants were finalized in September 2022. The show features a mix of celebrities from various fields, including television, film, music, and sports.

## Concept
The concept of the show remains the same as previous seasons, where a group of contestants, known as "housemates," live together in a specially designed house with cameras and microphones recording their every move.

## Development
The development of the season began several months before the premiere, with the production team working on the concept, casting, and logistics.

## Eye Logo
The eye logo for the season features a futuristic design with a hint of Bollywood glamour. The logo was unveiled on 26 September 2022.

## House
The Bigg Boss house for season 16 is located in Goregaon, Mumbai, and features a unique design with a mix of modern and traditional elements. The house has several rooms, including a kitchen, living area, bedroom, and garden.

## Release
The season premiered on 1 October 2022 with a grand opening episode featuring Salman Khan and the contestants.

# Housemates status

Gran Hermano is a reality television series produced in Argentina based on the Dutch production Big Brother. The tenth season of the show premiered on March 13, 2016, and concluded on December 1, 2016. The season was hosted by Jorge Rial and produced by Endemol Argentina.

article:
**United States**

The United States of America, commonly referred to as the United States or America, is a federal republic comprising fifty states, a federal district, and several territories. It is one of the world's most ethnically diverse and multicultural nations, founded on democratic principles and shaped by a strong tradition of individualism and innovation. Located in North America, the United States is bordered by Canada to the north, Mexico to the south, the Atlantic Ocean to the east, and the Pacific Ocean to the west. With a population of over 331 million people, it is the third most populous country in the world.

**Etymology**

The name "United States of America" was first used in the Declaration of Independence, adopted on July 4, 1776. The term "America" comes from the Italian explorer Amerigo Vespucci, who was the first European to recognize the New World as a separate continent. The name "United States" was chosen to reflect the unity of the thirteen colonies that declared independence from Great Britain.

**History**

### Indigenous peoples

The first human habitation of the Americas dates back to at least 15,000 years ago, with various Native American tribes developing complex societies and cultures across the continent. There were over 500 distinct Native American tribes, each with their own languages, customs, and traditions.

### European settlement and conflict (1607–1765)

The first successful English colony was established at Jamestown, Virginia in 1607. Over the next several decades, English, Spanish, French, and Dutch colonies were established along the eastern seaboard. The early colonial period was marked by conflict between Native American tribes and European settlers, as well as between rival European powers.

### American Revolution and the early republic (1765–1800)

Tensions between the colonies and Great Britain led to the outbreak of the American Revolutionary War in 1775. The Continental Army, led by George Washington, defeated the British at Yorktown in 1781, securing independence for the United States. The Constitution, adopted in 1787, established a federal system of government and enshrined the principles of democracy and individual rights.

### Westward expansion and Civil War (1800–1865)

The United States expanded its territory through the Louisiana Purchase of 1803 and the Mexican-American War of 1846–1848. The issue of slavery became increasingly divisive, culminating in the Civil War of 1861–1865. The Union, led by President Abraham Lincoln, ultimately prevailed over the Confederacy, abolishing slavery and preserving the unity of the nation.

### Post–Civil War era (1865–1917)

The late 19th and early 20th centuries saw rapid industrialization, urbanization, and immigration in the United States. The country emerged as a global economic and military power, with the Spanish-American War of 1898 marking the beginning of its rise as a world power.

### Rise as a superpower (1917–1945)

The United States entered World War I in 1917 and played a significant role in the Allied victory. The Roaring Twenties saw a period of economic prosperity and cultural transformation, followed by the Great Depression of the 1930s. The United States played a leading role in the Allied victory in World War II, emerging as one of the world's two superpowers.

### Cold War (1945–1991)

The post-war period saw the emergence of the Cold War, a decades-long conflict between the United States and the Soviet Union. The United States played a leading role in the formation of the United Nations and the development of the European Union, while also engaging in a series of proxy wars and espionage operations against the Soviet Union.

### Contemporary (1991–present)

The collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991 marked the end of the Cold War and the beginning of a new era of global politics. The United States has continued to play a leading role in international affairs, with a focus on counter-terrorism, economic globalization, and the promotion of democracy and human rights.

**Geography**

### Climate

The United States has a diverse climate, ranging from tropical in Hawaii and Florida to polar in Alaska. The country is prone to natural disasters such as hurricanes, tornadoes, and earthquakes.

### Biodiversity and conservation

The United States is home to a wide range of ecosystems, including forests, grasslands, deserts, and wetlands. The country has a number of national parks and wildlife refuges, and is home to a diverse range of wildlife, including bears, wolves, and eagles.

**Government and politics**

### National government

The federal government is divided into three branches: the legislative, executive, and judicial. The President serves as head of state and government, while Congress is responsible for lawmaking. The Supreme Court is the highest court in the land, with the power to interpret the Constitution and federal laws.

### Political parties

The United States has a two-party system, with the Democratic and Republican parties dominating national politics. There are also several smaller parties, including the Libertarian Party and the Green Party.

### Subdivisions

The United States is divided into fifty states, each with its own government and laws. There are also several territories, including Puerto Rico, Guam, and the U.S. Virgin Islands.

### Foreign relations

The United States has diplomatic relations with over 180 countries, and is a member of a number of international organizations, including the United Nations, NATO, and the G7.

### Military

The United States has a large and technologically advanced military, with a budget of over $700 billion. The country has a significant presence in several regions, including the Middle East, Asia, and Europe.

### Law enforcement and criminal justice

The United States has a decentralized system of law enforcement, with responsibility divided between federal, state, and local agencies. The country has a high incarceration rate, with over 2.3 million people in prison or jail.

**Economy**

### Science, technology, spaceflight and energy

The United States is a global leader in scientific research and innovation, with a strong tradition of technological entrepreneurship. The country has a significant space program, with NASA playing a leading role in exploration and development.

### Transportation

The United States has a well-developed transportation network, with a strong emphasis on highways, air travel, and shipping. The country is also investing in high-speed rail and other forms of sustainable transportation.

**Demographics**

### Population

The United States has a population of over 331 million people, with a diverse range of ethnic and racial groups.

### Language

English is the most widely spoken language in the United States, with Spanish and Chinese also widely spoken.

### Immigration

The United States has a long tradition of immigration, with over 14% of the population born abroad.

### Religion

The United States is a majority Christian country, with a significant number of Jews, Muslims, and people of other faiths.

### Urbanization

The United States is an urbanized country, with over 85% of the population living in cities or metropolitan areas.

### Health

The United States has a high life expectancy and access to quality healthcare, but also struggles with obesity, smoking, and other public health challenges.

### Education

The United States has a decentralized system of education, with responsibility divided between federal, state, and local governments. The country has a strong tradition of higher education, with many of the world's top universities.

**Culture and society**

### Literature

American literature is known for its diversity and innovation, with authors such as Mark Twain, Ernest Hemingway, and Toni Morrison making significant contributions.

### Mass media

The United States has a large and influential media industry, with a strong emphasis on television, film, and online media.

### Theater

American theater is known for its diversity and innovation, with a strong tradition of musical theater and experimental performance.

### Visual arts

The United States has a thriving visual arts scene, with a strong emphasis on contemporary art and photography.

### Music

American music is known for its diversity and innovation, with genres such as jazz, blues, and hip-hop making significant contributions.

### Fashion

The United States is a global leader in fashion, with a strong emphasis on designer clothing and accessories.

### Cinema

American cinema is one of the most influential and successful in the world, with a strong emphasis on blockbuster films and independent cinema.

### Cuisine

American cuisine is known for its diversity and innovation, with a strong emphasis on burgers, pizza, and other comfort foods.

### Sports

The United States is a sports-loving country, with a strong emphasis on American football, basketball, baseball, and other sports.

* Outline of the United States

The United States abortion protests refer to a series of demonstrations and rallies that took place across the country in response to the leaked draft opinion and subsequent overturning of Roe v. On May 2, 2022, a draft opinion written by Justice Samuel Alito was leaked to the press, revealing the Supreme Court's intention to overturn Roe v. Wade. ## Overturning of Roe v. Wade

On June 24, 2022, the Supreme Court issued its decision in Dobbs v. Jackson Women's Health Organization, effectively overturning Roe v. Wade and ending the constitutional right to abortion. The Boycott of Russia and Belarus refers to the economic sanctions and boycotts imposed on Russia and Belarus by various countries and organizations in response to the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine. The boycotts have had far-reaching consequences for the economies of both countries, as well as for international relations.

# Overview

The boycotts were initiated in response to Russia's military invasion of Ukraine, which began on February 24, 2022. The invasion was widely condemned by the international community, and many countries quickly imposed economic sanctions on Russia and Belarus. The sanctions included restrictions on trade, investment, and travel, as well as asset freezes and other financial penalties.

The boycotts have had significant economic consequences for Russia and Belarus. Russia's economy has been severely impacted, with the ruble plummeting in value and inflation soaring. Belarus has also suffered significant economic losses, with many countries suspending trade and investment.

article:
2022 AFF Championship

The 2022 AFF Championship, also known as the 2022 ASEAN Football Federation Championship, was the 14th edition of the AFF Championship, the primary international football tournament for national teams affiliated with the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN). The tournament was held from 20 December 2022 to 16 January 2023 in two countries, Thailand and Indonesia.

# Format

The tournament featured 11 teams from ASEAN, divided into two groups of five and six teams, respectively. The top two teams from each group advanced to the knockout stage, consisting of semi-finals and a final. The semi-finals were played in a two-legged format, with the winner determined by aggregate score. The final was played as a single match, with extra time and penalties used to determine the winner if necessary.

# Qualification

All 11 AFF member associations entered the tournament. There was no qualification process, as all member associations were guaranteed a spot in the tournament.

# Draw

The draw for the tournament was held on 30 July 2022 in Bangkok, Thailand. The teams were divided into two pots, with the top three teams in the AFF rankings in Pot 1 and the remaining teams in Pot 2. The teams were then drawn into two groups, with the top team in each pot placed in Group A and the remaining teams drawn randomly.

# Squads

Each team was allowed to name a squad of up to 30 players for the tournament. The squads were announced on 15 December 2022.

# Officials

The tournament featured 24 referees and 48 assistant referees from ASEAN countries. The referees were appointed by the AFF Referees Committee.

# Venues

The tournament was held in two countries, Thailand and Indonesia. The venues used were:

* Thammasat Stadium in Pathum Thani, Thailand

article:
Joan of Arc
================

Joan of Arc, also known as "The Maid of Orléans," was a French heroine and Catholic saint who led the French army to several victories during the Hundred Years' War. Born on January 6, 1412, in the village of Domremy, Joan's life was marked by a series of extraordinary events that have become legendary in French history.

Name
-----

Joan of Arc's birth name was Jehanne d'Arc, which translates to "Joan of Arc" in English. She was also known as "La Pucelle d'Orléans" or "The Maid of Orléans," a nickname that referred to her role in liberating the city of Orléans from the English siege.

Birth and Historical Background
---------------------------------

Joan of Arc was born in the village of Domremy, which is located in the northeastern part of France. At the time of her birth, France was in the midst of the Hundred Years' War, a conflict that had begun in 1337 and would last for another 75 years. The war was fought between the English and the French, with the English seeking to claim the French throne. The war had a devastating impact on France, causing widespread destruction and economic hardship.

Early Life
------------

Joan of Arc grew up in a peasant family and was raised in a devoutly Catholic household. Her father, Jacques d'Arc, was a farmer who also served as a local official. Her mother, Isabelle Romée, was a homemaker who taught Joan how to spin, sew, and cook. Joan had three brothers and a sister, and the family lived a simple life in a small cottage.

Chinon
--------

In 1429, at the age of 17, Joan traveled to the city of Chinon, where she petitioned Robert de Baudricourt, the garrison commander, for an escort to take her to the French court at Chinon. She claimed to have received visions from God that instructed her to drive the English out of France and crown the Dauphin, Charles VII, as the rightful king of France. Baudricourt was initially skeptical of Joan's claims, but eventually he was won over by her conviction and determination.

Military Campaigns
-------------------

Joan of Arc's military campaigns began in April 1429, when she led a small army to the city of Orléans, which had been under siege by the English for over a year. She arrived at the city on April 29 and quickly became a symbol of hope for the besieged inhabitants.

### Orléans

Joan of Arc's arrival at Orléans was met with skepticism by the city's defenders, who had been under siege for over a year. However, Joan quickly won them over with her bravery and determination. She led a series of successful attacks against the English, eventually forcing them to lift the siege on May 8, 1429.

### Loire Campaign

After the victory at Orléans, Joan of Arc led a campaign to drive the English out of the Loire Valley. She captured several key cities, including Jargeau, Meung-sur-Loire, and Beaugency. The campaign was marked by a series of victories, but also by a serious injury that Joan suffered at the siege of Jargeau.

### Coronation and Siege of Paris

In July 1429, Joan of Arc led the French army to the city of Reims, where Charles VII was crowned as the rightful king of France. The coronation was a major victory for Joan and the French, but it was followed by a series of setbacks. The French army was defeated at the siege of Paris, and Joan was captured by the English on May 23, 1430.

### Campaign against Perrinet Gressart

In the spring of 1430, Joan of Arc led a campaign against Perrinet Gressart, a French nobleman who had allied himself with the English. The campaign was marked by a series of victories, but it was ultimately unsuccessful. Joan was captured by the English on May 23, 1430.

### Siege of Compiègne and Capture

In May 1430, Joan of Arc led a small army to the city of Compiègne, which was under siege by the English. The siege was unsuccessful, and Joan was captured by the English on May 23, 1430.

Trials and Execution
---------------------

Joan of Arc was put on trial by the English, who accused her of heresy and witchcraft. The trial was a sham, and Joan was denied the right to a fair defense.

### Trial

The trial of Joan of Arc began on February 21, 1431, and lasted for several months. Joan was interrogated by a panel of church officials and lawyers, who sought to extract a confession from her. She was denied the right to a lawyer and was subjected to physical and emotional abuse.

### Execution

Joan of Arc was executed by burning at the stake on May 30, 1431. The execution was carried out in the market square of Rouen, and it was witnessed by a large crowd. Joan's death was a tragic event that shocked the French people and cemented her place as a national heroine.

### Aftermath and Rehabilitation Trial

In the years following Joan's execution, there was a growing movement to clear her name and rehabilitate her reputation. In 1456, a rehabilitation trial was held, and Joan was declared innocent of the charges against her. The trial was a major victory for Joan's supporters, and it paved the way for her canonization as a saint.

Visions
--------

Joan of Arc claimed to have received visions from God that instructed her to drive the English out of France and crown the Dauphin, Charles VII, as the rightful king of France. Her visions were a central part of her identity and her mission, and they played a key role in her military campaigns.

Clothing
---------

Joan of Arc wore men's clothing, which was a common practice among women who served in the military during the Middle Ages. She wore a suit of armor and carried a sword, and she was known for her bravery and her military skills.

Legacy
--------

Joan of Arc's legacy is complex and multifaceted. She is remembered as a military leader and a symbol of France, but she is also revered as a saint and a heroic woman.

### Military Leader and Symbol of France

Joan of Arc is remembered as a brilliant military leader who played a key role in the French victory over the English. She is a symbol of French patriotism and a reminder of the country's rich history and cultural heritage.

### Saint and Heroic Woman

Joan of Arc is revered as a saint and a heroic woman who embodied the values of courage, determination, and faith. She is a role model for women around the world, and her legacy continues to inspire and empower people to this day.

article:
Survivor Series: WarGames (2022)
=====================================

Survivor Series: WarGames was a professional wrestling pay-per-view (PPV) and livestreaming event produced by WWE. It took place on November 26, 2022, at the TD Garden in Boston, Massachusetts. This was the 36th annual Survivor Series event and the first to feature the WarGames match, a concept originally used by World Championship Wrestling (WCW).

Production
------------

### Background

The event was announced on July 16, 2022, with tickets going on sale on July 22. The event was originally scheduled to take place at the Amway Center in Orlando, Florida, but was later moved to the TD Garden in Boston, Massachusetts.

### Storylines

The event featured several matches that resulted from scripted storylines, where wrestlers portrayed heroes, villains, or less distinguishable characters in scripted events that built tension and culminated in a match or series of matches. The main feud heading into the event was between The Bloodline (Roman Reigns, Jey Uso, Jimmy Uso, Sami Zayn, and Solo Sikoa) and The Brawling Brutes (Sheamus, Butch, and Ridge Holland), Drew McIntyre, and Kevin Owens.

Event
--------

### Preliminary matches

The event kicked off with a five-on-five women's Survivor Series match, where Team Belair (Bianca Belair, Alexa Bliss, Asuka, Mia Yim, and Becky Lynch) faced Team Damage Control (Bayley, Dakota Kai, IYO SKY, Nikki Cross, and Rhea Ripley). The match saw Team Belair emerge victorious, with Belair and Lynch being the sole survivors.

The next match saw the United States Championship on the line, as Seth Rollins defended against Bobby Lashley and Austin Theory in a triple threat match. Rollins retained the title after pinning Theory.

### Main event

The main event of the evening was a WarGames match between The Bloodline (Roman Reigns, Jey Uso, Jimmy Uso, Sami Zayn, and Solo Sikoa) and The Brawling Brutes (Sheamus, Butch, and Ridge Holland), Drew McIntyre, and Kevin Owens. The match saw The Bloodline emerge victorious, with Reigns pinning McIntyre to win the match.

Reception
------------

### Commercial

The event was a commercial success, with WWE reporting a sold-out crowd of 15,609 at the TD Garden. The event also generated significant revenue through pay-per-view buys and merchandise sales.

### Critical

The event received generally positive reviews from critics, with many praising the WarGames match and the women's Survivor Series match. The event was also notable for being one of the first WWE pay-per-view events to feature a significant amount of blood, with several wrestlers bleeding during their matches.

Aftermath
----------

### Raw

The following night on Raw, The Bloodline celebrated their victory in the WarGames match, with Roman Reigns declaring that they were the most dominant force in WWE. The celebration was interrupted by Kevin Owens, who challenged Reigns to a match for the Undisputed WWE Universal Championship.

### SmackDown

On the following week's SmackDown, The Brawling Brutes (Sheamus, Butch, and Ridge Holland) faced The Usos (Jey Uso and Jimmy Uso) in a number one contender's match for the Undisputed WWE Tag Team Championship. The match saw The Usos emerge victorious, earning a title shot against The New Day (Kofi Kingston and Xavier Woods).

Results
----------

* Team Belair (Bianca Belair, Alexa Bliss, Asuka, Mia Yim, and Becky Lynch) defeated Team Damage Control (Bayley, Dakota Kai, IYO SKY, Nikki Cross, and Rhea Ripley) in a five-on-five women's Survivor Series match
* Seth Rollins (c) defeated Bobby Lashley and Austin Theory in a triple threat match to retain the United States Championship
* The Bloodline (Roman Reigns, Jey Uso, Jimmy Uso, Sami Zayn, and Solo Sikoa) defeated The Brawling Brutes (Sheamus, Butch, and Ridge Holland), Drew McIntyre, and Kevin Owens in a WarGames match

References
----------

---------------

The 2023 Spanish general election is scheduled to take place on or before December 10, 2023. The election will be held to elect the members of the 15th Cortes Generales, the unicameral parliament of Spain. In the run-up to the election, various organizations have conducted opinion polls to gauge voting intentions and sentiment among the electorate.

# Electoral polling

Order of Battle of the Russian Invasion of Ukraine

The order of battle of the Russian invasion of Ukraine refers to the disposition and organization of the Russian and Ukrainian forces during the ongoing conflict that began in 2022. This article provides an overview of the military units, commanders, and administrative structures involved in the conflict.

# Russian Forces in 2022

## Administrative Chain of Command

The Russian forces involved in the invasion of Ukraine were under the command of the Russian Ministry of Defense, led by Sergei Shoigu. The operational command was exercised by the General Staff of the Russian Armed Forces, headed by Valery Gerasimov. The Russian forces were divided into several operational-strategic commands, including the Western Military District, the Southern Military District, and the Central Military District.

## Initial Force Groupings

The initial Russian force groupings involved in the invasion of Ukraine included the 1st Guards Tank Army, the 6th Combined Arms Army, the 20th Guards Combined Arms Army, and the 8th Guards Combined Arms Army. These forces were primarily drawn from the Western Military District and the Southern Military District. The Russian Airborne Troops, including the 76th Guards Air Assault Division and the 98th Guards Airborne Division, also played a key role in the initial stages of the conflict.

## Russian Leaders 2022-23

Key Russian leaders involved in the invasion of Ukraine included:

* Sergei Shoigu, Minister of Defense
* Valery Gerasimov, Chief of the General Staff
* Alexander Dvornikov, Commander of the Southern Military District
* Sergey Surovikin, Commander of the Aerospace Forces
* Andrey Kartapolov, Commander of the Western Military District

# Russian Forces

## Mercenaries

Russian mercenaries, including the Wagner Group and the PMC Redut, played a significant role in the conflict. These groups were primarily composed of private military contractors who were recruited from various sources, including former Russian military personnel and foreign fighters.

## Militias

Russian-backed militias, including the Donetsk People's Republic (DPR) and the Luhansk People's Republic (LPR), also participated in the conflict. These militias were composed of local separatist fighters who were supported by the Russian military.

## Reserve Units of the Russian Armed Forces

Reserve units of the Russian Armed Forces, including the Territorial Troops and the Mobilization Human Reserve, were also involved in the conflict. These units were composed of former military personnel who were recalled to active duty during the conflict.

## Chechens

Chechen forces, including the Kadyrovtsy, played a significant role in the conflict. These forces were primarily composed of Chechen fighters who were loyal to the Russian-backed government of Chechnya.

## Spetsnaz Units

Russian Spetsnaz units, including the 22nd Spetsnaz Brigade and the 24th Spetsnaz Brigade, also participated in the conflict. These units were composed of elite special forces personnel who were trained for unconventional warfare and counter-terrorism operations.

## Joint Group of Forces

The Joint Group of Forces (JGF) was a Russian military task force that was established to coordinate the activities of the various Russian forces involved in the conflict. The JGF was composed of representatives from the Russian military, the Russian Airborne Troops, and the Russian Navy.

# Ukrainian Forces

The Ukrainian forces involved in the conflict included the Ukrainian Armed Forces, the Ukrainian National Guard, and various volunteer battalions. The Ukrainian military was primarily composed of regular army units, including the 1st Tank Brigade, the 72nd Mechanized Brigade, and the 95th Airborne Brigade. The Ukrainian Air Force also played a significant role in the conflict, with its fighter aircraft and helicopters providing close air support to Ukrainian ground forces.

Moon Knight is a television miniseries based on the Marvel Comics character of the same name. The series premiered on Disney+ on March 30, 2022, and consists of six episodes. It is the sixth television series in the Marvel Cinematic Universe (MCU) produced by Marvel Studios, and follows the story of Marc Spector, a former Marine who becomes the avatar of the Egyptian god Khonshu.

#Premise
The series follows Marc Spector, a former Marine who suffers from dissociative identity disorder. Marc becomes the avatar of the Egyptian god Khonshu, who has chosen him to be his earthly representative. As Marc's alternate personalities emerge, he must navigate his complex relationships and confront his troubled past. Along the way, he discovers that he has been tasked with protecting the world from supernatural threats, and must balance his dual identities as Marc Spector and Moon Knight.

#Cast and characters
The series features a diverse cast, including Oscar Isaac as Marc Spector / Moon Knight, a complex and troubled character with multiple personalities. Ethan Hawke plays Arthur Harrow, a cult leader who serves as the primary antagonist of the series. May Calamawy plays Layla El-Faouly, an archaeologist and Marc's love interest. F. Murray Abraham voices Khonshu, the Egyptian god who has chosen Marc as his avatar. The series also features a number of supporting characters, including David Ganly as Billy Fitzgerald and Ann Akin as Donna.

#Episodes

The filming process was extensive, with a number of different cameras and techniques used to capture the series' complex and non-linear narrative.

The production team used a combination of practical and digital effects, with a focus on creating a sense of realism and authenticity. The editors worked closely with the showrunner and head writer to create a sense of coherence and continuity, reflecting the series' complex and non-linear narrative.

##Music

The score was designed to be flexible and adaptable, allowing for a range of different environments and situations. The music was also designed to be culturally sensitive, reflecting the series' Egyptian and Middle Eastern influences.

#Marketing

The campaign was designed to create a sense of mystery and intrigue, reflecting the series' complex and non-linear narrative. The campaign also focused on highlighting the series' unique blend of action, adventure, and supernatural elements.

#Release

article:
Pishdadian Dynasty

The Pishdadian dynasty is a legendary royal house in Persian mythology, known for its heroic kings and its role in the early history of Iran. The dynasty is said to have ruled from the dawn of time to the rise of the Kayanian dynasty, and its stories have been preserved in various forms of Persian literature, including the Shahnameh and the works of the Muslim historian al-Tabari.

# Origins, etymology and sources

The origins of the Pishdadian dynasty are shrouded in mystery, and different sources provide varying accounts of its beginnings. The name "Pishdadian" is believed to be derived from the Persian word "pishdad," meaning "benefactor" or " ancestor." The dynasty is said to have been founded by the mythical king Gayomart, who is described as the first ruler of the world.

The primary sources for the history of the Pishdadian dynasty are the Shahnameh, a epic poem written by Ferdowsi in the 10th century, and the works of the Muslim historian al-Tabari, who wrote in the 9th century. These sources provide a wealth of information about the kings of the Pishdadian dynasty, their deeds, and their struggles against various enemies.

# The Shahnameh and Zoroastrian tradition

## Overview

The Shahnameh is one of the most important sources for the history of the Pishdadian dynasty. Written by Ferdowsi in the 10th century, the epic poem provides a comprehensive account of the kings of the dynasty, from Gayomart to the rise of the Kayanians. The Shahnameh is based on earlier oral traditions and draws heavily from Zoroastrian mythology.

## The kings

The Shahnameh describes the Pishdadian kings as heroic rulers who fought against various enemies, including the forces of darkness and chaos. The first king of the dynasty, Gayomart, is said to have been a wise and just ruler who established the foundations of civilization. He was succeeded by his son, Hoshang, who is credited with the discovery of fire and the establishment of agriculture.

The most famous king of the Pishdadian dynasty is probably Tahmuras, who is said to have ruled for 30 years and expanded the empire through conquest. He is also credited with the defeat of the demon king Ahriman, who had been terrorizing the world.

Other notable kings of the Pishdadian dynasty include Jamshid, who is said to have been a wise and just ruler, and Fereydun, who is credited with the division of the world into four quarters.

# Tabari and the Muslim narratives

## The first Pishdadian kings and the conflict with Iblis

The works of al-Tabari provide an alternative account of the Pishdadian dynasty, one that is influenced by Islamic theology and mythology. According to Tabari, the first king of the dynasty was Gayomart, who is described as a righteous and just ruler. However, he is also said to have been deceived by the devil Iblis, who tempted him to disobey God's commands.

The conflict between Gayomart and Iblis is a recurring theme in Tabari's account of the Pishdadian dynasty. Iblis is described as a powerful and cunning enemy who seeks to destroy humanity and undermine the authority of the Pishdadian kings.

## From Jam al-Shidh to Zaw: al-Dahhak and war with the Turks

Tabari's account of the Pishdadian dynasty also includes a detailed description of the wars fought by the kings against various enemies, including the Turks. One of the most famous kings of the dynasty is al-Dahhak, who is said to have ruled for 1,000 years and fought against the Turks and other enemies.

Al-Dahhak is described as a powerful and wise ruler who expanded the empire through conquest. However, he is also said to have been corrupted by power and greed, and his reign was marked by tyranny and oppression.

# Significance

The Pishdadian dynasty plays a significant role in Persian mythology and literature. The stories of the kings and their deeds have been preserved in various forms of literature, including the Shahnameh and the works of al-Tabari.

The Pishdadian dynasty is also important for its historical significance. The kings of the dynasty are said to have established the foundations of civilization and fought against various enemies to protect their people.

# Notes

The Pishdadian dynasty is a legendary royal house that is said to have ruled from the dawn of time to the rise of the Kayanian dynasty. The stories of the kings and their deeds have been preserved in various forms of Persian literature, including the Shahnameh and the works of al-Tabari.
